'''Harry Kesten''' (19 November 1931, [[Germany]]) is an American [[mathematician]] best known for his work in [[probability]], most notably on [[random walks]] and [[percolation theory]].

== Biography ==

Kesten grew up in the [[Netherlands]], where he moved with his parents in 1933 to escape the [[Nazi]]s.  He received his Ph.D. in 1956 at [[Cornell University]] under supervision of [[Mark Kac]].  He was an instructor at [[Princeton University]] and the [[Hebrew University]] before returning to Cornell where he is now professor [[emeritus]] of mathematics.

== Mathematical work ==
Kesten's work includes a number of fundamental contributions, including the following.
* Showing that amenability is equivalent to zero spectral gap and that a regular tree of degree <math>d</math> has spectral radius <math>2\sqrt{d-1}</math><ref>Harry Kesten, Symmetric random walks on groups. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 92 1959 336--354.</ref>
* His work with [[Hillel Furstenberg]] on products of random matrices<ref>Hillel Furstenberg and Harry kesten, Products of random matrices, Ann. Math. Statist. 31 (1960), 457–469.</ref>
* Enumerations of [[self-avoiding walk]]s and a "pattern theorem".<ref>Harry Kesten, On the number of self-avoiding walks. J. Mathematical Phys. 4 1963 960--969.</ref><ref>Harry Kesten, On the number of self-avoiding walks. II.  J. Mathematical Phys.  5  1964 1128--1137.</ref>
* Resolving a conjecture of [[Paul Erdős|Erdős]] and Szűsz on the discrepancy of irrational rotations<ref>{{cite journal|author=Harry Kesten|title=On a conjecture of Erdős and Szüsz related to uniform distribution mod 1|journal=Acta Arith.|volume=12|date=1966|pages=193--212|url=https://eudml.org/doc/204796}}</ref>
* Kesten did much work on [[percolation]] including proving that the critical probability of bond percolation on the square lattice equals 1/2,<ref>Harry Kesten, The critical probability of bond percolation on the square lattice equals 1/2.  Comm. Math. Phys.  74  (1980), no. 1, 41--59.</ref> demonstrating the so-called scaling relations<ref>Harry Kesten, Scaling relations for 2D-percolation.  Comm. Math. Phys.  109  (1987),  no. 1, 109--156.</ref> and writing the first book on percolation directed towards mathematicians.<ref>{{Citation | author= Harry Kesten | title= Percolation Theory for Mathematicians | year =1982 | url = http://www.math.cornell.edu/~kesten/kesten-book.html}}</ref>
* Giving an upper bound for the growth of arms in [[diffusion-limited aggregation]]<ref>Harry Kesten, How long are the arms in DLA?  J. Phys. A  20  (1987),  no. 1, L29--L33.</ref>
* His work with Vladas Sidoravicius on the spread of an infection in a moving population<ref>Harry Kesten and Vladas Sidoravicius, The spread of a rumor or infection in a moving population. Ann. Probab. 33 (2005), no. 6, 2402–2462.</ref><ref>Harry Kesten and Vladas Sidoravicius, A shape theorem for the spread of an infection. Ann. of Math. (2) 167 (2008), no. 3, 701–766.</ref>

==Awards and honors==
Kesten was a [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim fellow]], [[Sloan Fellowship|Alfred P. Sloan Fellow]], received the [[Brouwer Medal]] in 1981, the [[Steele Prize]]<ref>[http://www.ams.org/notices/200104/comm-steele.pdf 2001 Steele Prizes, Volume 48, Number 4], ''[[Notices of the AMS]]'', April 2001.</ref> for Lifetime Achievement from the [[American Mathematical Society|AMS]], and the [[Pólya Prize (SIAM)|George Pólya Prize]] from the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]].  He is also a member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] and a correspondent member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.knaw.nl/en/members/correspondents/4350 |title=H. Kesten |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref> In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-01-27.</ref>
